text: japan is set to have a new prime
minister the decision made by the ruling
party in the last few hours after
yoshide sugar decided to stand down
after just a year in the post live to
singapore now mariko is there watching
events for us mariko who's won this
battle then to be the ldp's new leader
and also the next prime minister
well lucy it's been confirmed that fumio
kishida who's a former foreign minister
of japan has won that leadership battle
as you said it was the ruling party's
leadership contest and he will most
certainly be confirmed as the country's
100th prime minister on the 4th of
october when parliament holds a session
but it was really interesting to watch
the runoff vote because he wasn't
exactly the most popular among japanese
voters in fact taro corner a very high
profile minister was more popular but it
wasn't about what the public wanted it
was about who was more popular among the
ruling parties lawmakers as well as its
members and even though mr kashida has
been described by his critics especially
in comparison to someone like mr corner
as boring and dull
he had the backing of the party's
veteran politicians and he was long seen
as a future leadership material so
following his victory this is what he
said to the party's members
well
i will with all my energy get straight
to work
party members around the country and
members of parliament please work with
me
he's got a strong political pedigree
morico but the big question is can he
win the next election
well as you say the country has to hold
a general election by the end of next
month and we know that the ruling
party's popularity has suffered
significantly because the government has
pushed ahead to host the tokyo olympics
despite a strong public opposition a lot
of voters weren't exactly happy with how
the ldp's government has been handling
the pandemic either
though i have to say the opposition
hasn't been too strong so it is
quite possible that the ldp
could win once again of course it has uh
ruled japan almost continuously uh since
the end of the second world war uh and
mr kishida because he's quite new and
the public don't exactly know him he
could be enjoying a honeymoon period but
when it comes to his policies i don't
think we expect a lot of changes from
the current administration of yoshihide
suga
foreign policies for example he was
rather critical of china during the
debate in the leadership election but
he's not as nationalistic as other
candidates for example though i have to
say when it comes to the economy he was
quite critical of the economic policy of
former prime minister shinzo abe known
as abenomics saying that it only made
the rich richer and he wants to
distribute the wealth more fairly so
there might be some changes there but in
terms of overall policies i don't think
we expect a lot of changes from the ldp
mariko good to see you thanks for
joining us from singapore
